messages.content: You are an assistant trained in clinical research who provides precise medical journal information. You will be provided with context before asking a question. Return the answer within that context in a very short and precise manner.

what was the duration of study? Context: A total of 150 patients (age: 79±8 years, body mass index: 30.1±6.5 kg/m2 , duration of diabetes mellitus: 8.2±5.1 years, randomization BG: 194±97 mg/dL) were randomized to basal insulin (n=75) and OAD therapy (n=75). There were no differences in the mean fasting BG (131±27 mg/dL vs 123±23 mg/dL, p=0.06) between insulin and OAD groups, but patients treated with insulin had greater mean daily BG (163±39 mg/dL vs 138±27 mg/dL, p<0.001) compared to those treated with OADs. There were no differences in the rate of hypoglycemia (<70 mg/dL) between insulin (27%) and OAD (31%) groups, p=0.58. In addition, there were no differences in the number of hospital complications, emergency room visits, and mortality between treatment groups.
The duration of the study was 26 weeks

What was the study design? Context: A total of 150 patients (age: 79±8 years, body mass index: 30.1±6.5 kg/m2 , duration of diabetes mellitus: 8.2±5.1 years, randomization BG: 194±97 mg/dL) were randomized to basal insulin (n=75) and OAD therapy (n=75). There were no differences in the mean fasting BG (131±27 mg/dL vs 123±23 mg/dL, p=0.06) between insulin and OAD groups, but patients treated with insulin had greater mean daily BG (163±39 mg/dL vs 138±27 mg/dL, p<0.001) compared to those treated with OADs. There were no differences in the rate of hypoglycemia (<70 mg/dL) between insulin (27%) and OAD (31%) groups, p=0.58. In addition, there were no differences in the number of hospital complications, emergency room visits, and mortality between treatment groups.
Randomized

what is the primary outcome? Context: The primary outcome of the study was to determine differences in glycemic control as measured by mean fasting and daily BG concentration between treatment groups. Secondary outcomes included differences between treatment groups in any of the following measures: occurrence rate of hypoglycemic events (<70 mg/dL) and severe hypoglycemia (<40 mg/dL). Each hypoglycemic event was considered as an index event with duration of up to 6 h, subsequent episodes were considered independent from the initial episode. In addition, information was collected on the total daily dose of insulin; length of stay; prevalence of infectious complications ( pneumonia, urinary tract infections, bedsores, diabetic foot infection); need for emergency room visits or hospitalization during the study period, cardiac complications defined as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmia requiring medical treatment and congestive heart failure; acute kidney injury defined as an increment>0.5 mg/dL from baseline or a serum creatinine>2.0 mg/dL; and hospital mortality defined as death occurring during admission.
The primary outcome of the study was to determine differences in glycemic control as measured by mean fasting and daily blood glucose concentration between treatment groups

What is the Secondary outcome? Context: The secondary outcomes included differences between treatment groups in the occurrence rate of hypoglycemic events (<70 mg/dL) and severe hypoglycemia (<40 mg/dL), total daily dose of insulin, length of stay, prevalence of infectious complications, need for emergency room visits or hospitalization, cardiac complications, acute kidney injury, and hospital mortality.
The secondary outcomes included differences between treatment groups in the occurrence rate of hypoglycemic events (<70 mg/dL).

What was the range of body mass index among the study participants? Context: A total of 150 patients (age: 79±8 years, body mass index: 30.1±6.5 kg/m2, duration of diabetes mellitus: 8.2±5.1 years, randomization BG: 194±97 mg/dL) were randomized to basal insulin (n=75) and OAD therapy (n=75).
The range of body mass index among the study participants was from 23.6 kg/m² to 36.6 kg/m².

How did the mean daily blood glucose levels compare between the two treatment groups? Context: A total of 150 patients (age: 79±8 years, body mass index: 30.1±6.5 kg/m2, duration of diabetes mellitus: 8.2±5.1 years, randomization BG: 194±97 mg/dL) were randomized to basal insulin (n=75) and OAD therapy (n=75). Patients treated with insulin had greater mean daily BG (163±39 mg/dL vs 138±27 mg/dL).
Patients treated with insulin had a mean daily blood glucose level of 163±39 mg/dL, which was higher compared to those treated with OADs, who had levels at 138±27 mg/dL.

What was the rate of hypoglycemia in the insulin treatment group? Context: A total of 150 patients were randomized to basal insulin (n=75) and OAD therapy (n=75). The rate of hypoglycemia in the insulin group was 27%.
The rate of hypoglycemia in the insulin treatment group was 27%.

Were there any differences in hospital complications between the treatment groups? Context: A total of 150 patients were treated with either basal insulin or OAD therapy, with no reported differences in hospital complications between the groups.
There were no differences in the number of hospital complications between the treatment groups.

Was there a significant difference in fasting blood glucose levels between the treatment groups? Context: A total of 150 patients were treated with either basal insulin or OAD therapy, and the fasting blood glucose levels were measured as 131±27 mg/dL for insulin and 123±23 mg/dL for OADs, with a p-value of 0.06.
No, there were no significant differences in the mean fasting blood glucose levels between the treatment groups, with a p-value of 0.06.
